title: Hollister Carnegie Library
text:
The Hollister Carnegie Library (previously: Hollister Free Public Library; now Hollister City Hall) is located on 375 Fifth Street in <a href="Hollister%2C%20California">Hollister, California</a>, US. Established in 1912 as a <a href="Carnegie%20library">Carnegie library</a>, decades later, it was re-purposed as a <a href="city%20hall">city hall</a>. The building is part of the downtown's National Register-listed <a href="Historic%20districts%20in%20the%20United%20States">historic district</a>, and was entered itself into the <a href="National%20Register%20of%20Historic%20Places%20listings%20in%20San%20Benito%20County%2C%20California">National Register</a> on March 26, 1992.
History.
The city's <a href="public%20library">public library</a>, established in 1884, transitioned into the Hollister Library Association, the Mechanics Library Association, and the <a href="Woman%27s%20Christian%20Temperance%20Union">Woman's Christian Temperance Union</a> reading room. Though the library underwent an expansion after moving into a house on Fifth Street in the early 20th century, it was considered to be too small for the community. After receiving a $10,000 grant from the <a href="Andrew%20Carnegie">Andrew Carnegie</a> Library Foundation in 1910, construction of a Carnegie library began in 1911 at 375 Fifth Street. Designed by <a href="William%20Binder">William Binder</a> of <a href="San%20Jose%2C%20California">San Jose</a>, the contractor was E. J. Sparling of Hollister. Costs associated with the project included US$2,034 for the lot, $9,983 for the building, and $500 for the furnishings. In 1960, the Holister library and the <a href="San%20Benito%20County%2C%20California">San Benito County</a> library consolidated, moving into a new building at 470 Fifth Street, while the Carnegie building was re-purposed as a city hall.
Architecture and fittings.
Set back from the street, the slightly raised site contains a retaining wall, lawn, garden area, walkway, and brick path.
The one story building with basement was designed in the <a href="Neoclassicism">Type A Classical Revival</a> style. Its particular <a href="classicism%23In%20architecture">classicism</a> architecture style was characterized as being unusually inhibited. There is an <a href="asphalt">asphalt</a> roof, molded panels, Ionic columns, exterior and interior stairways, casement windows, and bracketed sills. The structure was considered to be well adapted to its site as the <a href="reinforced%20concrete">reinforced concrete</a> foundation and walls made sense for a city situated on the <a href="Calaveras%20Fault">Calaveras Fault</a>. A rear expansion occurred in 1986.
